abstract.text: Let Game Center store and forward match data between players in a turn-based game.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Starting turn-based matches and passing turns between players

inlineContent.text: In a turn-based game, players take turns to advance gameplay, such as in chess, checkers, and similar board games.

The player who creates a match selects opponents and then takes the first turn. Then you pass the playerâ€™s turn, other game data, and the next participant to GameKit. GameKit saves the match data in Game Center, which sends the invitations to the other players. Game Center passes the turn to the next participant who accepts their invitation, until all participants reach an outcome or the match ends.
Players can participate in multiple concurrent matches that continue even after players quit a game. Game Center stores open and completed matches until the player explicitly removes them.
You manage turn-based matches through the GameKit turn-based APIs, specifically by using the
object that Game Center passes between participants. The match object contains the following information:
Status of the match
Participants and current participant
Status and outcomes of individual participants
A message for participants about the most recent turn
Your game-specific data
For design guidance, see
The code examples in this article use GameKit asynchronous methods that you invoke from an
method or within a
structure. For details about asynchronous flows, see
First, create a

object that contains the parameters of your turn-based game. You can set the number of players, apply groups and attributes to filter the matches, provide an invitation message, and set other criteria.
To get the maximum number of players Game Center supports for turn-based games, pass
to the
method.

Let players create a new match and select opponents by using the provided GameKit turn-based interface. Similar to how the process works in the real-time game interface, the player creates a match by tapping the plus button (+) in the upper-right corner. In the next few screens, the player invites players and, optionally, fills empty slots using automatch.
In your code, use the following steps to present the turn-based matchmaker interface:
Create a

Configure the view controller before presenting it. Optionally, set the view controllerâ€™s

to remove ongoing matches that appear under Your Turn and Their Turn. Otherwise, the player can select an existing match rather than create a new one. For more information about handling existing matches, see the
section below.
Implement the
protocol methods to handle cancellations and errors.
Then, present the turn-based matchmaker view controller to the local player.
Alternatively, create your own custom interface, and then programmatically find opponents and accept invitations using the

content.text: Present the gameplay interface for the player to take their turn

inlineContent.text: Before sending invitations to other players, GameKit invokes the

protocol method for the local player to take the first turn. Later, GameKit invokes this method each time it becomes the playerâ€™s turn until the player reaches an outcome or the match ends. Implement this method to present the gameplay interface that lets the player take their turn.
To receive the
callbacks, conform your game object to the

protocol and register it with the local player object. Register for callbacks immediately after you authenticate the local player because the system brings your game to the foreground or launches it to deliver important turn-based events. For more information about authentication, see
Then implement the
method to perform the following tasks:
Retain the
object that GameKit passes to this method, or retain its
property. During gameplay, get the current match object by passing the match ID to the
class method.
Update the gameplay interface by obtaining the latest game data from the match object using the
property. If itâ€™s the first turn, the game data is

If the match
property is
, configure the gameplay interface according to whose turn it is. Use the
property to determine whether itâ€™s the local playerâ€™s turn.
Present your gameplay interface to the local player.

content.text: Pass the turn to the next participant

inlineContent.text: After the player takes their turn, pass the turn to the next participant based on your game rules and logic. Implement your game to do the following:

Create an array of match participants in the order you want Game Center to pass the turn. If communication fails or a participant doesnâ€™t respond, Game Center passes the turn to the next participant in the array. Start with the participants in the
object. For example, exclude the current participant and other participants who, for whatever reason, arenâ€™t active.
Create a
representation of your game data that GameKit saves and forwards to the next participant. Ensure that the size of the match data doesnâ€™t exceed the
property. For example, use the
class to convert your game data to a
object.
Call the
method, passing the next participantâ€™s array, current game data, and optional timeout for the participant to take their turn.

code: try await match.endTurn(withNextParticipants: nextParticipants, turnTimeout: GKTurnTimeoutDefault, match: gameData)

inlineContent.text: If this is the first turn in the match, Game Center sends the invitations to other participants and then passes the turn to the next participant who accepts their invitation.
Alternatively, use the

method to save the game data without passing the turn to the next participant. For example, save and forward game data to other participants while the player takes a more complicated, multiple-step turn.
After the first turn, Game Center manages the status of participants for you by sending invitations and continuing to fill empty slots if you use automatch.

To join the match, a participant taps the Game Center invitation that appears on their device, and then taps the Accept button. If necessary, the system launches your game or brings it to the foreground. The player can also tap the match under New Invitations in the turn-based matchmaker interface when you present it.
When the local player joins a match, GameKit invokes the
method. Implement this method to show the gameplay interface with the current game data, and if itâ€™s the local playerâ€™s turn, let them take it.
Optionally, implement the
method to notify the local player when GameKit sends the invitations.

Enhance your game to show the status, name, and avatar of participants in the match when turn-based events occur. Also, be sure to update your interface when participants decline invitations or forfeit the match.
Implement the
method to perform the following tasks:
Get the list of all participants using the
property and get the participant taking their turn using the
property.
Show when participants accept their invitations and are actively playing using the
property. During the first turn, the status of other participants is
because Game Center hasnâ€™t sent the invitations. Later, the status transitions through the
possible values until the participant exits the match when the status becomes
If the
property is
, display more details that become available using the
property. Display the participantâ€™s name using the
property, and their avatar using the
method.

code: // Get the opponent's name and avatar.
let image = try await participant.player.loadPhoto(for: GKPlayer.PhotoSize.small)

inlineContent.text: If the
property is
, show the outcome of the participant using the
property. For example, show whether a participant wins, loses, or forfeits a match.

A player can continue a match if they donâ€™t forfeit it when they exit or quit your game. In the turn-based matchmaker interface, the player opens an existing match by selecting it under Your Turn or Their Turn.
When the player selects an open match, GameKit invokes the
method. Implement this method to present the match using the current game data in the match object, and if itâ€™s the local playerâ€™s turn, let them take it.
GameKit also invokes the
method if the player selects an ended match under Completed and then clicks the View Game button on the next screen.
If the match
property is
, show the outcomes of the participants and the final game data from the match object.
If you donâ€™t want existing matches to appear in the interface, set the view controllerâ€™s
to
before presenting it.
Alternatively, implement a custom interface that lets players manage existing matches. Use the
method to load the matches from Game Center.

A player can forfeit an open match using the turn-based matchmaker interface. The player taps the information button next to a match under Your Turn or Their Turn, and on the next screen, taps the Forfeit button in the upper-right corner. The player can also forfeit a match from the list by sliding the match to the left and tapping the Remove button. Players might also forfeit a match using a control in your gameplay interface.
GameKit invokes the
method in the game instance of the next participant. If the player removes a match that appears under Completed, GameKit deletes the match from Game Center without notifying your game.
Implement the
method to update your interface when the status of a participant changes to
. If the local player canâ€™t continue gameplay because the number of active participants drops below the minimum number of players, end the match, as described in the next section.
To programmatically forfeit a match, call either of the following methods, depending on whether itâ€™s the local playerâ€™s turn:
Pass
as the match outcome. If itâ€™s the local playerâ€™s turn, pass an array of next participants and the current game data.

code: try await match.participantQuitInTurn(with: GKTurnBasedMatch.Outcome.quit, nextParticipants: nextParticipants, turnTimeout: GKTurnTimeoutDefault, match: gameData)

inlineContent.text: When a player forfeits a match, notify participants using the APIs described in
. Optionally, implement the
protocol method to notify players.
You programmatically end a match depending on your game rules and when participants reach an outcome. You can only end the match when itâ€™s the local playerâ€™s turn.
To end a match, set the outcomes of all the participants in the match object using the
property. For example, if the local player wins the match, set the current participantâ€™s outcome to
and the other participantsâ€™ outcomes to
Then call either of the following methods:
Optionally, pass updated game data, leaderboard scores, and achievements. If the game data doesnâ€™t change, you can pass the existing data.
When a match ends, notify the participants using the APIs described in
. Optionally, implement the
protocol method to notify participants.

abstract.text: A Boolean value indicating whether GameKit can add badges to a turn-based game icon.
An encoder that stores an objectâ€™s data to an archive referenced by keys.
A false value.
Enable players to interact with friends, compare leaderboard ranks, earn achievements, and participate in multiplayer games.
A protocol that handles events for Game Center players.
An object that encapsulates the parameters to create a real-time or turn-based match.
Returns the maximum number of players allowed in the match request for a given match type.
A turn-based match hosted by Game Center.
A string to display for the player.
Loads a photo of the player from Game Center.
The protocol that handles turn-based and data-exchange events between participants in a match.
Handles when the player uses Game Center to start a match with other players.
Handles when the match ends.
Handles turn-based match events, such as accepting invitations, passing turns, and saving match data.
Handles when the current participant wants to quit a match.
Exchange request information that participants send in a turn-based match.
Details about a recipientâ€™s response to an exchange request.
An object that encapsulates the match data for games where players take turns.
The participant loses the match.
The participant forfeits the match.
The participant wins the match.
A match that finishes.
A match that participants are actively playing.
Accepts an invitation for the local player to join a turn-based match.
The participant whose turn it is.
Declines an invitation for the local player to join a turn-based match.
Ends the match.
Ends the match while submitting scores and achievements for all of the participants.
Passes the turn from the current participant to the next participant.
Creates a new match or finds an existing match that needs a player.
Fetches the turn-based matches from Game Center that the local player participates in.
The game-specific data that you store in Game Center and pass between participants through a match object.
The maximum size of the match data.
A unique identifier for the turn-based match.
Forfeits the match on behalf of the local player when itâ€™s their turn.
Forfeits the match on behalf of the local player when itâ€™s not their turn.
The players that participate in a turn-based match.
Saves your match data in Game Center without ending the turn.
The state of the match, such as whether the match is open or has ended.
An interface that allows a player to invite other players to a turn-based match and automatch to fill any empty slots.
The mode that a multiplayer game uses to find players.
A Boolean value that determines whether the view controller shows existing matches.
A protocol that handles when the status of turn-based matchmaking changes.
A participant in a turn-based match.
The state the participant is in during the match.
The participant joins the match and is an active player.
The participant leaves the match.
The participant represents an unfilled position in the match that Game Center promises to fill when needed.
The conclusion or results of a participant in a match.
The player object containing the participant details.
The status of the participant.
Confirm player credentials and device capabilities and check for account restrictions.
Develop games where multiple players take turns and can exchange data while waiting for their turn.
Add the ability for players to exchange game data and send messages while waiting for their turns.

media-3894599.alt: An iPhone screen showing the turn-based matchmaker view controllerâ€™s completed match detail view. The avatar and name of the player who created the match appear, followed by the View Game button and a list of participants with their avatars, names, and outcomes.

media-3894600.alt: An iPhone screen showing the turn-based matchmaker view controller interface displaying the participants, and the Invite Friends and the Start Game buttons.

media-3894601.alt: An iPhone screen showing the Game Center invitation banner that displays the name of the game and an invitation message. Below the banner are the Accept and Decline buttons.

media-3894721.alt: An iPhone screen showing the turn-based matchmaker view controller with the open match details. The playerâ€™s avatar and name appear at the top with a Play your turn button on the bottom. The Forfeit button appears in the upper-right corner.

media-3901330.alt: An iPhone screen showing the turn-based matchmaker view controller interface displaying the list of existing matches in the Your Turn and Their Turn sections. The Completed Games section displays games that are done. The plus button (+) for creating a new game appears in the upper-right corner.
